name: Sodium Hypochlorite (Bleach)
shortDescription: Chlorine-based oxidizing bleach used for whitening and disinfection.
uses: Mildew/mold removal, sanitizing siding, decks, concrete; organic stain removal.
precautions: Corrosive to skin/eyes; produces toxic gases if mixed with acids or ammonia; wear gloves, goggles, and respirator for fumes; control runoff.
mixingNote: Typically diluted for surface cleaning; follow product label for concentration.

name: Sodium Percarbonate (Oxygen Bleach)
shortDescription: Oxygen-based powdered bleach that releases hydrogen peroxide.
uses: Brightening wood and concrete; gentler mold/algae removal alternative to chlorine.
precautions: Oxidizer; eye/skin irritant; keep dry in storage; use gloves and goggles.
mixingNote: Dissolve per manufacturer's instructions; active at warm temperatures.

name: Sodium Hydroxide (Caustic Soda)
uses: Strips heavy grease, oils, some coatings; used in heavy-duty concrete and equipment cleaners.
precautions: Highly corrosive — causes severe burns and eye damage. Use acid/alkali-resistant PPE, face shield, and avoid inhalation.
mixingNote: Prepare diluted solutions carefully, add pellets to water slowly; never add water to pellets.

name: Potassium Hydroxide (KOH)
shortDescription: Strong alkaline used in some heavy-duty detergents.
uses: Degreasing and heavy cleaning where strong alkalinity is required.
precautions: Same as sodium hydroxide — corrosive; full PPE required.
mixingNote: Follow product instructions for dilution and temperature.

name: Trisodium Phosphate (TSP)
uses: Surface prep, removing built-up grime and grease before painting or sealing.
precautions: Irritant; environmental concerns (eutrophication). Contain rinse water and limit phosphate discharge.
mixingNote: Use as directed; avoid overuse near drains.

name: Sodium Metasilicate
shortDescription: Alkaline builder used in industrial cleaners.
uses: Boosts detergency, emulsifies oils and greases.
precautions: Corrosive; can cause skin/eye burns. Use gloves and eye protection.
mixingNote: Dissolve per label; avoid incompatible mixes.

name: Nonionic Surfactants
shortDescription: Wetting agents and detergents (e.g., alkyl polyglucosides).
uses: General-purpose cleaners; reduce surface tension to improve cleaning.
precautions: Mild-moderate irritant; choose biodegradable types where possible.
mixingNote: Typically added at low concentrations per formulation.

name: Anionic Surfactants
shortDescription: Detergents for removing soils and greases.
uses: Concrete and siding cleaners; strong foaming detergents.
precautions: Irritant; do not mix with cationic disinfectants.
mixingNote: Follow dilution guidance; rinsing prevents residue.

name: Cationic Surfactants / Quats
shortDescription: Disinfectant and algaecide class (quaternary ammonium compounds).
uses: Disinfecting surfaces and algae control in some treatments.
precautions: Irritant and toxic to aquatic life; incompatible with anionic detergents and some oxidizers.
mixingNote: Observe required contact time for disinfection; dilute per label.

name: Hydrochloric Acid (Muriatic Acid)
shortDescription: Strong mineral acid for removing mineral deposits and rust stains.
uses: Etching concrete, removing efflorescence and rust from masonry.
precautions: Highly corrosive and fuming; severe inhalation hazard and skin burns. Never mix with bleach.
mixingNote: Always add acid to water slowly; use acid-rated PPE and containment.

name: Phosphoric Acid
shortDescription: Acid cleaner used for rust and mineral removal.
uses: Concrete cleaning and rust stain removal; milder than HCl in some uses.
precautions: Corrosive; use PPE and contain runoff.

name: Oxalic Acid
shortDescription: Organic acid effective at rust and tannin stain removal.
uses: Rust stain extraction on concrete and wood tannin removal.
precautions: Toxic if ingested; skin/eye irritant. Use gloves and goggles.
mixingNote: Use in recommended dilute solutions; rinse thoroughly.

name: Citric Acid
shortDescription: Mild organic acid for descaling and stain removal.
uses: Mild mineral stain removal and pH adjustment; safer alternative for some uses.
precautions: Irritant at high concentrations; wear gloves and eye protection.
mixingNote: Dissolve to recommended concentration; safe disposal.

name: Enzymatic Cleaners
uses: Break down organic soils, odors, and biological stains.
precautions: Possible allergens; store per vendor guidance and use PPE.
mixingNote: Effective within specific pH and temperature ranges — follow label.

name: D-Limonene (Citrus Solvent)
shortDescription: Citrus-derived solvent for adhesive and heavy grease removal.
uses: Tar, sap, and adhesive removal; degreasing.
precautions: Flammable and possible skin sensitizer; use ventilation and gloves.
mixingNote: Used neat or diluted per product; avoid ignition sources.

name: Petroleum-based Solvents (Mineral Spirits)
uses: Paint thinning, adhesive and heavy oil removal.
precautions: Flammable and inhalation toxic; use respirator and fire controls.
mixingNote: Use in well-ventilated areas and per manufacturer guidance.

name: Chelating Agents (EDTA / GLDA)
shortDescription: Bind metal ions to improve cleaning performance.
uses: Scale control, stain removal, and improved rinsing.
precautions: Environmental persistence concerns for some chelants; prefer biodegradable options.
mixingNote: Follow formulation instructions; avoid unnecessary discharge.

name: Calcium Hypochlorite / Sodium Dichloroisocyanurate
shortDescription: Solid chlorine sources used in some disinfectant products.
uses: Disinfection and sanitizing when liquid bleach not used.
precautions: Strong oxidizers; store dry away from organics; reactive with acids; PPE required.
mixingNote: Dissolve per label and avoid mixing with incompatible chemicals.
